required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: S3 Root Pulsed Radiofrequency Added to Superior Hypogstric Plexus Block
clinical_study.official_title: the Added Analgesic Effect of S3 Root Pulsed Radiofrequency to Superior Hypogastric Plexus Block in Pelvic Cancer Pain. a Controlled, Randomized Study

brief_summary.textblock: The investigators hypothesis that adding pulsed radiofrequency neuromodulation at S3 nerve root to superior hypogastric plexus chemical neurolysis improves analgesia in patients with chronic pelvic cancer pain.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.time_frame: from 30 min. after procedure to 2 months after it

secondary_outcome.time_frame: during the block procedure and within the first 24 hours after the block
secondary_outcome.description: including transient paresthesia, rectal puncture, vascular penetration of one of the pelvic vessels, hematoma, infection, dural puncture, bowel/bladder dysfunction, pain on injection, hypotension from the sympathetic block or any other complication
The time required to perform the block

secondary_outcome.time_frame: in the first 24 hours after procedures and at 1,2,4 weeks and 2 months visits after it

arm_group.description: pulsed radiofrequency at S3 nerve root + superior hypogastric plexus block

intervention.intervention_name: pulsed radiofrequency at S3 root plus superior hypogastric plexus block
intervention.description: pulsed radiofrequency neuromodulation at S3 root plus superior hypogastric plexus chemical neurolysis

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- pelvic cancer patients
- with pelvic pain not responding to oral analgesic medications
- side effects of oral analgesic medications
Exclusion Criteria:
- patients with metastatic cancer disease
- patients with significantly impaired organ functions
- patients with bleeding diathesis
- patients with mental disabilities

responsible_party.investigator_title: Assisstant Professor of Anesthesia, ICU, and Pain management
